title: Decision Support
text:
The clinical burden from acute viral respiratory infections during winter months will often be the result of multiple concurrent epidemics. In 2022–2023, many countries experienced large overlapping epidemics of influenza, RSV and COVID-19, exerting unusual pressure on ICU capacity. Short-term forecasting of epidemic activity can help to enable rapid understanding of the status of concurrent epidemics and preparation for any increased impact on healthcare services.
The project has the following aims:

To develop enhanced methods for epidemic situational assessment of viral respiratory pathogens.
To generate real-time epidemic analysis, including forecasts, of COVID-19, influenza, and RSV during winter to support public health risk assessment and response.
To assess forecast utility and public health value through both statistical performance evaluation and engagement with public health partners.

Australian Consortium for Epidemic Forecasting & Analytics








Working to support the timely, effective response to epidemic diseases in Australia through real-time data analytics, modelling, and forecasting.





 



















Decision Support


Generate and share real-time analyses with Australian decision-makers and the public.













Methods and Tools


Advance methods and software tools for epidemic analysis.













Data


Inform the design of surveillance studies to optimise data collection for public health action.

title: About
text:
ACEFA aims to support the timely, effective response to epidemic diseases in Australia through real-time data analytics, modelling, and forecasting. Our work builds on a national seasonal influenza forecasting program (2014–19) and COVID-19 situational assessment consortium (2020–23).

Team
ACEFA involves multiple academic research groups from across Australia, including:

Infectious Disease Dynamics Unit, Centre for Epidemiology and Biostatistics Research, the University of Melbourne
Infectious Disease Ecology and Modelling group, Child Health Analytics Research Program, Telethon Kids Institute
Defence Science and Technology Group
Monash University
Infectious Disease Dynamics and Interventions Group, School of Population Health, University of New South Wales
Infectious Disease Epidemiology and Modelling, National Centre for Epidemiology and Population Health, Australian National University
Infectious diseases modelling and Epidemiology Group, Australian Institute of Tropical Health and Medicine, James Cook University
and Adelaide Data Science Centre, University of Adelaide

as well as international partners:

School of Mathematics and Statistics, University of Canterbury.
